body:
Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @hassox isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
The Linux Foundation CLA GitHub bot_
Signed

thanks for doing this, sorry for the delay here. 

Looking at the tests here, there appears to be a number of compilation issues caused by this, e.g., https://sponge.corp.google.com/target?id=cdc1fa6d-48f4-4caa-b5a9-ca5ccca1e5ad&target=grpc/ubuntu/pull_request/grpc_basictests_cpp_opt&searchFor=&show=ALL&sortBy=STATUS 

To reproduce (hopefully all) of those compilation issues, I suggest running something like

```
python tools/run_tests/run_tests.py -l c++ --build_only
```

locally.

Can we proceed with this after fixing these build issues?

Hi

Thanks for the heads up. I'm trying to run the tests but I can't get them running on my machine. I'm a bit of a n00b at the core code on gRPC and I seem to have some dependencies missing on my local machine.  This is the output of that command:

Any ideas on how to move forward?

Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @connorjacobsen isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
CLA GitHub bot_
Signed

> Any ideas on how to move forward?

Looks like gflags is needed in your dev environment. Can you install from here: https://gflags.github.io/gflags/?

[This doc](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) also has some tips for running the tests locally FYI

@apolcyn I think we got it building after adding gflags. Can you advise on next steps?

EDIT: Well, looked that way from mobile. From the web GUI looks like we're still waiting on the build to finish.

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```
@apolcyn Any tips to help get these last few checks passing?

please run `tools/buildgen/generate_projects.sh `, `tools/distrib/clang_format_code.sh `, and please fix copyrights until `tools/distrib/check_copyright.py` passes.

Also, because these testing .proto files are specific to ruby only, can we please move the new testing `.proto` files to be somewhere under `src/ruby/`, perhaps under `src/ruby/spec/pb/package_with_underscore/checker_spec.rb`? 

thanks

@apolcyn I am trying to run `tools/buildgen/generate_projects.sh` and getting the following error:

```bash
$ tools/buildgen/generate_projects.sh
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py", line 75, in <module>
    main()
  File "src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py", line 63, in main
    update_deps(deps_for, look_at, deps_trans, deps_external_trans, True, [])
  File "src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py", line 43, in update_deps
    update_deps(key, imp_proto, deps, deps_external, is_trans, visited)
  File "src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py", line 28, in update_deps
    with open(proto_filename) as inp:
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'grpc/testing/package_with_underscore/data.proto'
```

It appears that `grpc/testing/package_with_underscore/data.proto` _does_ exist. I also tried updating the `src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py` script to help with some debugging, but it doesn't appear my that my changes were actually doing anything. Is there some kind of checkin/build step that I am missing on either of these fronts? Any guidance would be greatly appreciated.

@connorjacobsen the problem is coming from [this logic](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/proto/gen_build_yaml.py#L42) in the `src/proto/gen_build.yaml.py`, where the script examines proto files that are imported by each proto file.

Change `import "grpc/testing/package_with_underscore/data.proto";` to `import "src/proto/grpc/testing/package_with_underscore/data.proto";` and this should work (this makes the import path consistent with the rest of the proto files under `src/proto`.

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```

@apolcyn One more for you, I'm now getting this error:

```shell
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "tools/buildgen/mako_renderer.py", line 31, in <module>
    from mako.lookup import TemplateLookup
ImportError: No module named mako.lookup
```

I pip installed Mako locally, but that didn't seem to do it. Nothing obvious in project docs/issues that would fix it either.
Also, excited that this is almost passing :)

@connorjacobsen for your earlier comment:

> I pip installed Mako locally, but that didn't seem to do it. Nothing obvious in project docs/issues that would fix it either.

I'm not sure what the cause is there, but FWIW the test infra that's running that script on kokoro installs it in [https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/tools/dockerfile/test/sanity/Dockerfile#L86](this way).

But it seems like an issue with mako not being installed. Personally, when running locally outside of docker, I use a python virtualenv and pip install mako for this, which works.

BTW the remaining test failure here is just a C++ formatter error and can be fixed with `tools/distrib/clang_format_code.sh`

@apolcyn I have addressed your comments.

A couple things worth noting:
- [This spec](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/ruby/spec/pb/health/checker_spec.rb) also has the conditional test that requires both `grpc_ruby_plugin` and `protoc` to be available. Is it weird that this new spec (which behaves similarly) is unconditional?
- This new test will break if `grpc_ruby_plugin` or `protoc` is unavailable.
- I am a newb at both bash and make, so I may have done it incorrectly, but it doesn't seem like adding the `make grpc_ruby_plugin -j8` actually did anything that changed the test environment. The plugin gets installed by the `sudo make install` that builds grpc from source, and I had to build `protoc` from source from the `third_party` directory. Any guidance you have on that would be useful. I suppose it will also be useful to see how CI responds.
- I moved the proto files to the test directory since that's the only place they're being used and it's for a ruby-specific bug fix. Happy to rename or move those protos.

Please let me know what you think about these changes. It also looks like CI is not happy with some of the bazel builds already :/

Of course I am happy to rebase and squash this PR into a single, descriptive commit message once you are happy with it and ready to merge.

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

@connor4312 for your questions: > This spec also has the conditional test that requires both grpc_ruby_plugin and protoc to be available. Is it weird that this new spec (which behaves similarly) is unconditional? > This new test will break if grpc_ruby_plugin or protoc is unavailable. > I am a newb at both bash and make, so I may have done it incorrectly, but it doesn't seem like adding the make grpc_ruby_plugin -j8 actually did anything that changed the test environment. The plugin gets installed by the sudo make install that builds grpc from source, and I had to build protoc from source from the third_party directory. Any guidance you have on that would be useful. I suppose it will also be useful to see how CI responds. I agree that it's odd that the current test is conditional on the plugin and protoc being available, but actually that test is something I would like to change (I would actually like to get both of these tests running under the automated unit test suite). Note that `make grpc_ruby_plugin` will make both the `protoc` and the `grpc_ruby_plugin` executables available under `/bins/{opt,dbg}/grpc_ruby_plugin` and `/bins/{opt,dbg}/protobuf/protoc`, and you should then be able to access those executables from within a subsequent test run (you shouldn't need `protoc` or the `grpc_ruby_plugin` to be installed or to be on the `PATH`). Without running this test the `grpc_ruby_plugin` built from HEAD, there is just not a good way to make sure that this new change is passing it's test.... Let me know if PR against your branch would be helpful; if so I could get to that by end of week.
@apolcyn Great. I'll take a stab at it today/tomorrow, I think I understand what you're saying and I think I know how to tackle it. Thank you!

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```
@apolcyn I think I've successfully done the above. Hopefully it builds.

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```
